Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
pslinv - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Screen.title: PSLINV Process
Screen.Label: PSLINV (PreStack Linearized INVersion)
General Parameters:
OPT_INPUT=
OPT_OUTPUT=
OPT_SD_OUT=
NUMTR_IN=
NUMTR_OUT=
NUM_PARMS=
FOLD_MIN=
ANG_FAR=
SCALE=
EXP_GARD=
FREQ_MIN=
DIAG_LOAD=
Parameters for A Priori Model Covariance:
CC_RVS_RVP=
CC_RDEN_RVP=
CC_RDEN_RVS=
SDR_RVS_RVP=
SDR_RDEN_RVP=
COV_DETERM=
Parameters to specify Background Vs/Vp:
OPT_AVE=
LEN_SMOOTH=
HDR_X=
HDR_Y=

Help.Tip: Whether input in angle gathers, A_AND_B pairs, or A_B_C triples.
Help.Text:
pslinv - OPT_INPUT
Whether input in angle gathers, A_AND_B pairs, or A_B_C triples.
 
 Default = ANGLE
 Allowed = ANGLE   (Input is angle gathers.)
 Allowed = A_AND_B (Input is intercept-gradient pair gathers.)
 Allowed = A_B_C   (Input is 3-trace A_B_C gathers.)
 
 If OPT_INPUT = ANGLE, header word 6 must contain reflection angle for each
 trace, in degrees.
 
 If OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, each 2-trace input gather must contain intercept(A)
 followed by gradient(B), where A and B are coefficients in the Shuey equation
 R = A + B*sin^2.
 
 If OPT_INPUT = A_B_C, each 3-trace input gather must contain the A, B and C
 traces in that order, where A, B and C are coefficients in the extended Shuey
 equation R = A + B*sin^2 + C*sin^2*tan^2.

Help.Tip: Output product desired.
Help.Text:
pslinv - OPT_OUTPUT
Output product desired.
 
 Default = 3
 Allowed = 2    RP, DSIGMA and RS;                         2-parameter.
 Allowed = 3    ZP, SIGMA and ZS;               INTEGRATED 2-parameter.
 Allowed = 4    D(LAMBDA-RHO) and D(MU-RHO);               2-parameter.
 Allowed = 5    LAMBDA-RHO and MU-RHO;          INTEGRATED 2-parameter.
 Allowed = 6    A, B and C (RP, GRAD, RVP);                3-parameter.
 Allowed = 7    RVP, RVS and RDEN;                         3-parameter.
 Allowed = 8    VP, VS and DEN;                 INTEGRATED 3-parameter.
 Allowed = 9    RP, RS and RDEN;                           3-parameter.
 Allowed = 10   ZP, ZS and DEN;                 INTEGRATED 3-parameter.
 Allowed = 11   RP, DSIGMA and RDEN;                       3-parameter.
 Allowed = 12   ZP, SIGMA and DEN;              INTEGRATED 3-parameter.
 Allowed = 13   D(LAMBDA-RHO), D(MU-RHO), RDEN;            3-parameter.
 Allowed = 14   LAMBDA-RHO, MU-RHO and DEN;     INTEGRATED 3-parameter.
 
 Options 2 to 5 are 2-parameter inversions; options 6 to 14 are 3-parameter
 inversions. (Note: Even though options 2 and 3 generate three output
 parameters, they are still TWO-parameter inversions because their three
 inverted quantities aren't independent; they are provided for convenience
 because users may wish to view all three of them.)
 
 Options 2, 4, 7, 9, 11 and 13 invert for CONTRASTS of rock properties
 across interfaces.
 
 Options 3, 5, 8, 10, 12 and 14 are integrated versions of options 2, 4, 7,
 9, 11 and 13 respectively. Integrated outputs are intended to represent
 actual LAYER properties, as opposed to contrasts between layers. These are,
 however, BAND-LIMITED results, with no information outside the bandwidth of
 the seismic data. Also, these results have arbitrary scale unless you've
 set the SCALE parameter just right.
 
 Option 6 outputs the coefficients A, B and C in the 3-parameter Aki and
 Richards equation  R = A + B*sin^2 + C*sin^2*tan^2. But this is more than
 a simple curve fit. In fact, option 6 is based on the same rock property
 model and a priori covariance as options 7 to 14; it inverts for rock
 property contrasts as in those other options, but then outputs the A, B
 and C coefficients equivalent to the inverted rock property contrasts.
 
 If OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, then only the 2-parameter options (2 - 5) are
 available.

Help.Tip: Whether to output standard deviations of inverted quantities.
Help.Text:
pslinv - OPT_SD_OUT
Whether to output standard deviations of inverted quantities.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES - Output standard deviation traces.
 Allowed = NO  - Don't output standard deviation traces.
 
 Setting OPT_SD_OUT = YES doubles the number of output traces by appending
 traces containing estimated standard deviations of the inverted quantities
 to each output gather. For example, if OPT_OUTPUT = 2, PSLINV would normally
 output 3 traces in each gather, containing RP, DSIGMA and RS in that order.
 If OPT_SD_OUT = YES, then 6 traces are output in each gather, containing:
 
         RP, DSIGMA, RS, SD(RP), SD(DSIGMA), SD(RS)
 
 in that order, where SD(x) denotes standard deviation of quantity x.
 
 Estimated standard deviations are available only when OPT_INPUT = ANGLE
 and DIAG_LOAD > 0.
 
 For integrated outputs (OPT_OUTPUT = 3, 5, 8, 10, 12 and 14), estimated
 standard deviations are actually those of the NON-integrated quantities;
 thus, they are identical to the standard deviations output when
 OPT_OUTPUT = 2, 4, 7, 9, 11 and 13, respectively.

Help.Tip: Value of NUMTR global upon input, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
pslinv - NUMTR_IN
Value of NUMTR global upon input, shown for reference.
 
 PSLINV requires gathered input. NUMTR for your input traces must be at
 least 2 for all options; it must be exactly 2 when OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B
 and must be exactly 3 when OPT_INPUT = A_B_C.

Help.Tip: Value of NUMTR global upon output, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
pslinv - NUMTR_OUT
Value of NUMTR global upon output, shown for reference.
 
 Number of traces in each output gather, corresponding to the number of
 output quantities (plus standard deviations of those quantities if
 OPT_SD_OUT=YES). Depending on your choice of OPT_OUTPUT:
 NUMTR_OUT will be 2 (or 4 if OPT_SD_OUT=YES) when OPT_OUTPUT = 4 or 5.
 NUMTR_OUT will be 3 (or 6 if OPT_SD_OUT=YES) for all other OPT_OUTPUT values.
 
 Note that when OPT_OUTPUT = 2 or 3, NUMTR_OUT will be 3, even though these
 are TWO-parameter inversions.

Help.Tip: Whether 2-parameter or 3-parameter inversion, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
pslinv - NUM_PARMS
Whether 2-parameter or 3-parameter inversion, shown for reference.
 
 NUM_PARMS will be 2 when OPT_OUTPUT = 2 to 5.
 NUM_PARMS will be 3 when OPT_OUTPUT = 6 to 14.
 
 Note that when OPT_OUTPUT = 2 or 3, PSLINV does TWO-parameter inversion, so
 NUM_PARMS = 2, although three (non-independent) quantities are computed and
 output (NUMTR_OUT = 3 or 6).

Help.Tip: Minimum # of live angle samples at any depth to attempt inversion.
Help.Text:
pslinv - FOLD_MIN
Minimum # of live angle samples at any depth to attempt inversion.
 
 Default = NUM_PARMS
 Allowed = int >= NUM_PARMS
 
 At each time/depth level, PSLINV will not attempt inversion unless the input
 gather contains at least this many live trace samples at that level.
 
 Active only when OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.

Help.Tip: Estimated far angle in original data, in degrees.
Help.Text:
pslinv - ANG_FAR
Estimated far angle in original data, in degrees.
 
 Default = 40.0
 Allowed = 84.26 > real > 0.0
 (Note: Upper limit of 84.26 degrees is the angle at which sin^2 = 0.99)
 
 This parameter is relevant only when OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, as in this case,
 PSLINV needs an estimate of the angle range that was originally in your data
 before reduction to intercept and gradient.
 
 In operation, when OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, the input A and B traces are used
 with the Shuey equation (R = A + B*sin^2) to generate model traces at angles
 zero and ANG_FAR. Then, these two traces are used as if OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.
 
 Considering that far angles actually achieved are depth dependent, you
 may base your ANG_FAR estimate on the depth of greatest interest.
 
 If input A_AND_B pairs were produced by AVAGRAD using the High Order AVA
 Offset Dependent Tuning Correction (NP_FIT = 3) option in AVAGRAD, it is
 best to specify a value for ANG_FAR which is considerably less than the far
 angle actually in your data (e.g., you might set ANG_FAR to only 10 degrees),
 because that NP_FIT = 3 option in AVAGRAD produces A_AND_B pairs which
 accurately match only the small-angle AVA behavior of your data.
 
 Active only when OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B.

Help.Tip: Scale factor to convert trace amplitudes to reflection coefficients.
Help.Text:
pslinv - SCALE
Scale factor to convert trace amplitudes to reflection coefficients.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real /= 0.0
 If you know the scale factor that will convert your input trace amplitudes
 to true reflectivity, setting this parameter will produce output with a
 more accurate amplitude scale. Otherwise, the output products will have an
 arbitrary scale.

Help.Tip: Exponent in Gardner's equation (rho = const * VP**EXP_GARD).
Help.Text:
pslinv - EXP_GARD
Exponent in Gardner's equation (rho = const * VP**EXP_GARD).
 
 Default = 0.25
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Gardner's equation is used in the TWO-parameter rock property inversions to
 eliminate a third independent parameter from the equations. This is done by
 assuming that the materials on both sides of an interface follow the Gardner
 equation.
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT = 2, 3, 4 or 5.

Help.Tip: Low-cut frequency to use for integrated products, in Hz.
Help.Text:
pslinv - FREQ_MIN
Low-cut frequency to use for integrated products, in Hz.
 
 Default = 3.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 The integration step in options 3, 5, 8, 10, 12 and 14 can introduce spurious
 low frequency energy outside the bandwidth of the seismic data. The FREQ_MIN
 parameter allows this noise to be removed after integration.
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT = 3, 5, 8, 10, 12 or 14.

Help.Tip: Diagonal load, in percent, for inverse calculations.
Help.Text:
pslinv - DIAG_LOAD
Diagonal load, in percent, for inverse calculations.
 
 Default = 5.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 Given noisy data, the diagonal load factor stabilizes the inversion.
 If the signal/noise ratio in your data is S/N (expressed in terms of
 power, not amplitude), the diagonal load should be chosen as:
 
                   DIAG_LOAD  =  100 / (S/N)
 
 which is simply the noise/signal ratio (multiplied by 100 because diagonal
 load is expressed as a percentage).
 
 Strictly speaking, DIAG_LOAD isn't a DIAGONAL load for 3-parameter inversions
 when OPT_INPUT = ANGLE, as it multiplies a NON-diagonal (inverse) covariance
 matrix incorporating your knowledge of correlations between rock properties.
 But DIAG_LOAD still plays the role of a stabilization factor and should still
 be selected according to signal/noise ratio based on the formula above.
 
 Active only when OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.  We assume that when OPT_INPUT =
 A_AND_B or A_B_C, signal/noise has already been accounted for in calculation
 of intercepts and gradients or A_B_C triples, so it would be redundant to do
 again in PSLINV.

Help.Tip: Correlation coefficient between RVS and RVP for model covariance.
Help.Text:
pslinv - CC_RVS_RVP
Correlation coefficient between RVS and RVP for model covariance.
 
 Default = 0.8
 Allowed = 1.0 > real > -1.0
 This parameter is used in specifying the a priori model covariance matrix
 for 3-parameter inversions when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE and DIAG_LOAD > 0.0.

Help.Tip: Correlation coefficient between RDEN and RVP for model covariance.
Help.Text:
pslinv - CC_RDEN_RVP
Correlation coefficient between RDEN and RVP for model covariance.
 
 Default = -0.2
 Allowed = 1.0 > real > -1.0
 This parameter is used in specifying the a priori model covariance matrix
 for 3-parameter inversions when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE and DIAG_LOAD > 0.0.

Help.Tip: Correlation coefficient between RDEN and RVS for model covariance.
Help.Text:
pslinv - CC_RDEN_RVS
Correlation coefficient between RDEN and RVS for model covariance.
 
 Default = -0.3
 Allowed = 1.0 > real > -1.0
 This parameter is used in specifying the a priori model covariance matrix
 for 3-parameter inversions when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE and DIAG_LOAD > 0.0.

Help.Tip: Ratio of Std Dev of RVS to Std Dev of RVP for model covariance.
Help.Text:
pslinv - SDR_RVS_RVP
Ratio of Std Dev of RVS to Std Dev of RVP for model covariance.
 
 Default = 1.8
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Standard deviation ratios are required in specifying the a priori model
 covariance matrix for 3-parameter inversions when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and
 OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE and DIAG_LOAD > 0.0.

Help.Tip: Ratio of Std Dev of RDEN to Std Dev of RVP for model covariance.
Help.Text:
pslinv - SDR_RDEN_RVP
Ratio of Std Dev of RDEN to Std Dev of RVP for model covariance.
 
 Default = 0.5
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Standard deviation ratios are required in specifying the a priori model
 covariance matrix for 3-parameter inversions when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and
 OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE and DIAG_LOAD > 0.0.

Help.Tip: Determinant of model covariance matrix, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
pslinv - COV_DETERM
Determinant of model covariance matrix, shown for reference.
 
 Determinant of your a priori model covariance matrix must be positive.
 
 Specification of model covariance applies only to 3-parameter inversions
 when OPT_OUTPUT > 5 and OPT_INPUT = ANGLE and DIAG_LOAD > 0.0.

Help.Tip: Choose PATH_VSVP using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
pslinv - SELECT_PATH_VSVP
Choose PATH_VSVP using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Pathname for a TRCIO trace file containing Vs/Vp ratios.
Help.Text:
pslinv - PATH_VSVP
Pathname for a TRCIO trace file containing Vs/Vp ratios.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 You must EITHER specify a trace file containing background Vs/Vp ratios
 OR manually enter (TIME, VS_VP) pairs to specify a single time-dependent
 Vs/Vp function. Background Vs/Vp ratios are needed in order to relate
 reflection amplitudes to rock property contrasts.
 
 If you specify a file, trace values in your file should be in the range
 0 < real <= 0.7. Hard zero (and negative) values in the file are
 interpreted as nil values, so are ignored and replaced with interpolated
 or extrapolated values.
 
 When specifying a trace file containing background Vs/Vp, parameters
 HDR_X and HDR_Y let you to specify which header words in this file denote
 X and Y locations. These X and Y locations must fill a rectangular grid and
 must be sorted in ascending order, with X increasing most rapidly.
 
 Please note, however, that X and Y locations of the seismic gathers to be
 inverted need NOT be sorted this way, and need not match the locations of
 Vs/Vp traces exactly, as the Vs/Vp values will be interpolated/extrapolated
 to the locations of your data. Also, the seismic sample rate and time range
 of the Vs/Vp traces need not coincide with those of the data being inverted.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_VSVP.
Help.Text:
pslinv - PATH_VSVP_INFO
Status of PATH_VSVP.

Help.Tip: Whether to average all Vs/Vp traces in the file into one.
Help.Text:
pslinv - OPT_AVE
Whether to average all Vs/Vp traces in the file into one.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 This allows suppressing the lateral variation in your Vs/Vp trace file by
 averaging all Vs/Vp traces into a single time-dependent Vs/Vp function and,
 then, using that function to invert your data. This is analogous to OPT_AVE
 in processes AVAST and AVAGRAD; however, the default in this process is
 OPT_AVE = NO, because it is assumed that when you specify PATH_VSVP, you do
 want a laterally varying background Vs/Vp.
 
 If OPT_AVE = YES, it is actually the SQUARES of the Vs/Vp values in the
 file which are averaged laterally.
 
 Active only when PATH_VSVP has been specified.

Help.Tip: Length of running average smoother for Vs/Vp ratios in file.
Help.Text:
pslinv - LEN_SMOOTH
Length of running average smoother for Vs/Vp ratios in file.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 Length, in seconds, of (vertical) running average smoother for the Vs/Vp
 values read from PATH_VSVP file. If LEN_SMOOTH = 0.0, then no smoothing is
 done. This is analogous to LEN_SMOOTH in processes AVAST and AVAGRAD;
 however, the default in this process is LEN_SMOOTH = 0.0, because it is
 assumed that any desired smoothing has already been done in generating the
 PATH_VSVP file.
 
 If LEN_SMOOTH > 0.0, smoothing is actually applied to the SQUARES of the
 Vs/Vp values read from the file.
 
 Active only when PATH_VSVP has been specified.

Help.Tip: CPS header word containing X locations in PATH_VSVP file.
Help.Text:
pslinv - HDR_X
CPS header word containing X locations in PATH_VSVP file.
 
 Default = 37
 Allowed = 1 - NWIH
 Make sure this header word is set properly in both your PATH_VSVP file and
 in the data you are inverting.
 
 Active only when PATH_VSVP is specified.

Help.Tip: CPS header word containing Y locations in PATH_VSVP file.
Help.Text:
pslinv - HDR_Y
CPS header word containing Y locations in PATH_VSVP file.
 
 Default = 38
 Allowed = 1 - NWIH
 Make sure this header word is set properly in both your PATH_VSVP file and
 in the data you are inverting.
 
 Active only when PATH_VSVP is specified.

Help.Tip: Trace times, in seconds, for specifying Vs/Vp ratios.
Help.Text:
pslinv - TIME
Trace times, in seconds, for specifying Vs/Vp ratios.
 
 Default = Single entry at time TSTRT
 Allowed = Real linked array: Values between TSTRT and end of trace.
 You must EITHER specify a trace file containing background Vs/Vp ratios
 OR manually enter (TIME, VS_VP) pairs to specify a single time-dependent
 Vs/Vp function. Background Vs/Vp ratios are needed in order to relate
 reflection amplitudes to rock property contrasts.
 
 If you manually enter (TIME, VS_VP) pairs, at least one such pair must be
 provided. TIME entries must be in increasing order but needn't cover the
 whole trace, as your VS_VP values will be interpolated/extrapolated to cover
 the trace.

Help.Tip: Background Vs/Vp ratio as slowly varying function of trace time.
Help.Text:
pslinv - VS_VP
Background Vs/Vp ratio as slowly varying function of trace time.
 
 Default = Single entry with value 0.5
 Allowed = Linked array: Values in range 0.7 >= real > 0.0
 You must EITHER specify a trace file containing background Vs/Vp ratios
 OR manually enter (TIME, VS_VP) pairs to specify a single time-dependent
 Vs/Vp function. Background Vs/Vp ratios are needed in order to relate
 reflection amplitudes to rock property contrasts.
 
 If you manually enter (TIME, VS_VP) pairs, at least one such pair must be
 provided. As it is actually the SQUARE of Vs/Vp which appears in the Aki and
 Richards approximation, your VS_VP will be squared, then linearly
 interpolated/extrapolated to cover the whole trace.
 
 The upper limit of VS_VP = 0.7 is nearly SQRT(0.5), which corresponds to
 Poisson's ratio = 0 or Lame parameter Lambda = 0.

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
pslinv - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
pslinv - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
pslinv - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
pslinv - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
pslinv - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
pslinv - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
pslinv - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
pslinv - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
pslinv - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
pslinv - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
pslinv - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : PSLINV    (PreStack Linearized INVersion)
 Category   : inversion
 Written    : 1992-02-21   by: Bob Baumel & Dapeng Wang
 Revised    : 2006-09-11   by: Tom Stoeckley
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Linearized inversion of prestack angle gathers.
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : No.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 
 PSLINV is a linearized inversion of pre-stack angle gathers (or intercept(A)
 gradient(B) or A_B_C trace gathers) to various 2-parameter and 3-parameter
 rock property and AVA attributes.
 
 
 Inversion Method
 
 PSLINV performs "linearized" inversion in that it's based on the Aki and
 Richards linearized approximation of the relationship between angle-dependent
 reflectivity and contrasts in material properties. Nonlinear effects are
 ignored or treated as known, smoothly varying "background" properties (e.g.,
 background Vs/Vp ratio is specified as a slowly varying function of travel-
 time in this implementation).
 
 Propagation velocity is assumed to be handled by previous processing (NMO,
 migration, etc.). Data is assumed to contain primaries only. Also, PSLINV
 does not attempt any nonlinear methods to extend the data bandwidth. (The
 FREQ_MIN parameter allows removing low frequency noise that may have been
 introduced by the integration step in some options.)
 
 
 Output Options
 
 2 vs. 3 Parameter Inversions
 
 Options 2 - 5 are two-parameter inversions in the sense that they invert
 for two independent rock properties. Actually, even these "two-parameter"
 options use the THREE-parameter Aki & Richards approximation, but they
 assume a "hard" Gardner constraint (specified by the EXP_GARD parameter)
 to eliminate density and then solve for only two rock properties.
 
 Options 6 - 14 are three-parameter inversions which use the three-parameter
 Aki & Richards approximation directly to solve for three rock properties.
 
 Options 2 and 3 are classified as TWO-parameter inversions, even though they
 generate three output parameters, because their three output quantities
 aren't independent (Any one of the outputs can be calculated from the other
 two); we provide these three outputs for convenience, as users may wish to
 view all three of them.
 
 Option 6 outputs the coefficients A, B and C in the expression:
        Reflectivity  =  A  +  B * sin^2  +  C * sin^2 * tan^2,
 but this is more than a simple curve fit. In fact, option 6 is based on the
 same rock property model and a priori covariance as options 7 to 14; it
 inverts for rock property contrasts as in those other options, but then
 outputs the A, B and C coefficients equivalent to the inverted rock property
 contrasts.
 
 When OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, only the 2-parameter options are available.
 
 Given the improved stabilization now in PSLINV (with DIAG_LOAD and a priori
 model covariance), it is worthwhile to always run three-parameter rather
 than two-parameter inversion whenever possible -- although, depending on
 data quality and angle range of your input data, you may or may not obtain
 usable results for the 3rd inverted parameter (density). Thus, two-parameter
 inversion should probably be limited to cases when you have no other choice;
 i.e., when you have only intercept and gradient data (OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B).
 
 
 Interface-Oriented vs. Layer-Oriented Outputs
 
 Options 2, 4, 7, 9, 11 and 13 invert for contrasts of rock properties across
 interfaces. Here, the inverted quantities are:
 
      "RP"     = P-Reflectivity = 0.5 * d(P-Impedance) / (P-Impedance)
      "RS"     = S-Reflectivity = 0.5 * d(S-Impedance) / (S-Impedance)
      "DSIGMA" = d(Poisson's ratio)
      "RVP"    = 0.5 * d(P-Velocity) / (P-Velocity)
      "RVS"    = 0.5 * d(S-Velocity) / (S-Velocity)
      "RDEN"   = 0.5 * d(Density) / (Density)
      "D(LAMBDA-RHO)" = 0.5 * d(Lambda*Density) / (Lambda*Density)
      "D(MU-RHO)"     = 0.5 * d(Mu*Density) / (Mu*Density)
 
 where "d" denotes a (vertical) difference in material properties across
 the interface. Lambda and Mu denote the Lame parameters.
 
 Options 3, 5, 8, 10, 12 and 14 are (band-limited) integrated versions of
 options 2, 4, 7, 9, 11 and 13 respectively. Here, the output quantities are:
 
      "ZP"    = 0.5 * log(P-Impedance)
      "ZS"    = 0.5 * log(S-Impedance)
      "SIGMA" = Poisson's ratio
      "VP"    = 0.5 * log(P-Velocity)
      "VS"    = 0.5 * log(S-Velocity)
      "DEN"   = 0.5 * log(Density)
      "LAMBDA-RHO" = 0.5 * log(Lambda*Density)
      "MU-RHO"     = 0.5 * log(Mu*Density)
 
 These integrated outputs are intended to represent LAYER properties, as
 opposed to contrasts between layers. These are still BAND-LIMITED results,
 with no information outside the bandwidth of the seismic data.
 
 For any of these interface-oriented or layer-oriented outputs, results will
 have arbitrary scale unless you set the SCALE parameter just right, to scale
 your input data to true reflectivity.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
 
 Three kinds of input data may be used by PSLINV:
 1. Angle gathers such as produced by partial stacking, e.g., from process
    AVAST.
 2. Intercept-and-gradient (A_AND_B) pairs, usually from process AVAGRAD.
 3. Three trace A_B_C gathers.
 
 The preferred sequence is to use angle gathers which have been filtered
 using the Wavelet Stretch Filtering (WSF) process and then input these
 gathers to PSLINV using the OPT_INPUT = ANGLE option. Removal of wavelet
 stretch is necessary in order to have any hope of recovering a third
 parameter in 3-parameter inversions.
 
 In the past, input data for PSLINV were often pre-processed with AVAGRAD to
 take advantage of Offset Dependent Tuning Correction (ODTC). If AVAGRAD has
 been run, the data have been reduced to Intercept-and-gradient pairs which
 would be input to PSLINV using OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B; and only two-parameter
 inversion options in PSLINV are available. On the other hand, leaving your
 data in angle gathers and filtering them with WSF seems to do a better job
 of removing offset dependent tuning and preserves the option to do a
 three-parameter inversion in PSLINV.
 
 If your data consists of partial-offset stacks (instead of partial-angle
 stacks), the only option for using PSLINV is to pre-process the data with
 AVAGRAD using the OPT_INPUT = OFFSET option in AVAGRAD before running PSLINV.
 
 When OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, you must also set the ANG_FAR parameter in order
 to specify the angle range of your input data (which would be evident when
 OPT_INPUT = ANGLE, but is no longer obvious after the data have been reduced
 to A_AND_B pairs). In operation, when OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, the input A and B
 traces are used with the Shuey equation to generate model traces at angles
 zero and ANG_FAR; then, these traces are used as if OPT_INPUT = ANGLE.
 
 
 Input Data Preparation
 
 If OPT_INPUT = ANGLE, input data will normally be angle gathers produced by
 AVAST.  The AVAST documentation discusses proper data preparation for that
 process. Angle gathers produced by AVAST should not have an amplitude balance
 applied but SHOULD be filtered with WSF to remove wavelet stretch.  Angle
 gathers should also be MUTED (head and tail) before input to PSLINV to remove
 any artifacts or filter tails at top and bottom of traces that might be
 misinterpreted as spurious AVA behavior. This muting is probably done most
 easily with the data sorted in common angle panels rather than the CMP angle
 gathers which must actually be input to PSLINV. Use a ZERO LENGTH TAPER in
 MUTE to avoid introducing tapers that PSLINV would interpret as AVA behavior!
 
 If OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, input will be intercept-gradient pair trace gathers
 normally produced by AVAGRAD (the intercept trace must be the first trace in
 the gather). These intercept-gradient gathers should not be altered before
 being input to PSLINV.
 
 If OPT_INPUT = A_B_C, input will be three-trace gathers containing the
 coefficients A, B and C (in that order) that fit the Aki & Richards equation
 R = A + B*sin^2 + C*sin^2*tan^2. These A_B_C triples may have been produced
 by the PSNINV (prestack nonlinear inversion) process.
 
 
 Choosing Diagonal Load
 
 The diagonal load factor DIAG_LOAD helps to stabilize the inversion in the
 presence of noise. If you can estimate the signal/noise ratio (S/N) in your
 data (expressed in terms of power, not amplitude), then a suitable diagonal
 load may be chosen as:
 
                   DIAG_LOAD  =  100 / (S/N)
 
 which is simply the noise/signal ratio (multiplied by 100 because diagonal
 load is expressed as a percentage).
 
 The DIAG_LOAD parameter is not available when OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B or A_B_C
 since, in those cases, signal/noise should have already been accounted for
 in the process of reducing your data to A_AND_B or A_B_C traces. It would be
 redundant to do signal/noise analysis again in PSLINV while inverting for
 rock properties.
 
 Note: Now that PSLINV has capability to specify a general covariance for the
 a priori model, the term involving the DIAG_LOAD parameter is no longer,
 strictly speaking, a DIAGONAL load. However, for backward compatibility, we
 haven't changed the name of this parameter.
 
 
 Choosing A Priori Model Covariance
 
 Three parameter inversions can be stablized by using an a priori model
 covariance specified by the five numbers:
    CC_RVS_RVP   = Correlation coefficient between RVS and RVP.
    CC_RDEN_RVP  = Correlation coefficient between RDEN and RVP.
    CC_RDEN_RVS  = Correlation coefficient between RDEN and RVS.
    SDR_RVS_RVP  = Ratio of Std Dev of RVS to Std Dev of RVP.
    SDR_RDEN_RVP = Ratio of Std Dev of RDEN to Std Dev of RVP.
 The defaults for these parameters are based on averages computed from
 several wells (These values may be revised in the future!). If you have
 well logs in your area, you may use process PSCOVAR to derive covariances
 specific for that region.
 
 
 Choosing traveltime dependent Vs/Vp
 
 If you have well logs for your area (including P-wave, S-wave and Density),
 process PSCOVAR can output a smoothed Vs/Vp trace which you can view in Cbyt
 to pick a time-dependent Vs/Vp function for use in PSLINV.
 
 
 QC of Results
 
 For most output options, standard deviations of the inverted quantities may
 be output by setting OPT_SD_OUT = YES, in order to estimate quality of the
 inverted results. Estimation of the standard deviations requires you to set
 DIAG_LOAD > 0, and is therefore not available when OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B or
 A_B_C.
 
 
 Backward Compatibility Notes
 
 The 2004-06-24 update to PSLINV includes a number of changes that don't
 preserve backward compatibility. Some points to note:
 
 As the VS_VP parameter has been changed from a scalar to an array, its value
 won't transfer from old work files built with the previous version. Thus, if
 the old job included a VS_VP value different from its default of 0.5, it will
 get reset to its default when reading the old work file, and you'll need to
 restore it manually in the new job.
 
 Several of the OPT_OUTPUT options have been renumbered. The old linear
 combination options (previously 4, 5 and 13) have been eliminated, as nobody
 ever used them. The two-parameter Lame parameter inversions, previously 14
 and 15, are now options 4 and 5. Options 13 and 14 are now three-parameter
 Lame parameter inversions.
 
 Three-parameter inversions with DIAG_LOAD > 0 won't give the same results as
 the previous version unless you set the a priori model covariance to match
 the covariance assumed implicitly by that older PSLINV, which (for options
 7 to 12) was an identity matrix in RP, RP-RS and RDEN. To match that
 assumption, you must now set the strange-looking values:
    CC_RVS_RVP     =  0.8164966  (=  SQRT(2/3))
    CC_RDEN_RVP    = -0.7071068  (= -SQRT(1/2))
    CC_RDEN_RVS    = -0.5773503  (= -SQRT(1/3))
    SDRAT_RVS_RVP  =  1.2247449  (=  SQRT(3/2))
    SDRAT_RDEN_RVP =  0.7071068  (=  SQRT(1/2))
 Option 6 (A_B_C output) with DIAG_LOAD > 0 would be still harder to match
 because you'd have to enter covariance values that depend on the Vs/Vp ratio.
 In the old version, option 6 assumed a covariance (identity matrix in A, B
 and C) inconsistent with the rock property inversions (options 7 to 12). In
 the new version, option 6 performs the SAME rock property inversion as
 options 7 to 14, then outputs the A_B_C values consistent with the inverted
 rock properties.

     Date        Author     Description
     ----        ------     -----------
 17. 2006-09-11  Stoeckley  Add call to pc_register_array_names for SeisSpace.
 16. 2006-04-04  Baumel     Added ability to read spatially-dependent Vs/Vp
                            from a trace file.
 15. 2006-01-10  B. Menger  Removed Unused Variables.
 14. 2005-01-17  Baumel     Add a priori model covariance for 3-parameter
                            inversions. Add OPT_INPUT = A_B_C, time-dependent
                            VS/VP, and 3-parameter Lame options (new options
                            13 and 14). Remove option 1 (A_AND_B output) which
                            duplicated functionality of AVAGRAD. Change action
                            of option 6 (A_B_C output) to assume same rock
                            property model as options 7 and above. Remove the
                            linear combination options (old options 4, 5 and
                            13). Rename the 2-parameter Lame options (old
                            options 14 and 15) to 4 and 5.
 13. 2002-04-17  Baumel     Add DIAG_LOAD and OPT_SD_OUT parameters; switch
                            2nd and 3rd parameters in options 2 and 3; change
                            3rd parameter in options 11 and 12 to Density
                            instead of P-Velocity.
 12. 2001-11-01  Baumel     Add statement to compile in new absoft compiler.
 11. 2001-10-04  Baumel     Add LAMBDA-RHO, MU-RHO options.
 10. 2001-04-10  Baumel     Documentation change warranted because AVAGRAD
                            now includes an OPT_INPUT = OFFSET option.
  9. 2001-02-01  Baumel     Converted to new system (Changes in conversion:
                            Add OPT_INPUT = A_AND_B, combine previous options
                            2, 3, 4 and 5 into new options 2 and 3; remove
                            the RVA option).
  8. 1999-06-09  Baumel     Remove (RVP,RVS) and (VP,VS) 2-parameter
                            inversion options (too sensitive to differential
                            Gardner assumption); also reduce default for FCUT.
  7. 1999-05-13  Baumel     Bug fix - include RVA in PSLINV_CSET calls.
  6. 1999-05-11  Baumel     Rename process to PSLINV. Provide band-
                            limited integration for all 2 and 3-param
                            inversion options; remove option for setting
                            a mute pattern within this process; add RVA
                            parameter; overhaul for F90 (FIX format).
  5. 1995-12-06  Baumel     Do "SAIL" for ALL params in options 3 & 10.
  4. 1995-11-14  Baumel     Avoid hard zero trace values (same as ASTK).
  3. 1995-04-04  Baumel     First version with 13 active options.
  2. 1995-02-28  Baumel     Interim version while modernizing program.
  1. 1992-02-21  D Wang     Original version of IMPD process.
